attributes.label: Michael Brauer
attributes.position: Professor, UBC Faculty of Medicine, UBC School of Population and Public Health

attributes.label: Linda Nowlan
attributes.position: Senior Director

attributes.label: Academic District Energy System
attributes.description: UBC continues to provide reliable, cost-effective, and increasingly sustainable utilities to its campus and broader community.  Three milestone projects helped UBC achieve a 34 per cent greenhouse gas (GHG) emission reduction in 2016 from 2007 levels. Looking ahead to 2020, UBC will be tripling the capacity of its biomass plant, energizing 70% of the ADES with clean waste wood, saving an additional $1.0 million annually and drastically reducing greenhouse gas emissions.

attributes.label: EcoTrek
attributes.description: ECOTrek involved retrofitting 288 UBC academic buildings to reduce energy and water consumption. The project goal was to reduce energy and water consumption in core academic buildings, along with associated greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions, thereby reducing the University’s energy costs. ECOTrek provided a mechanism to fund the renewal of campus facilities, and use new technologies to replace aging utility management infrastructure.

attributes.label: InSEAS (Interactive Study for the Environment and Its Aquatic Systems)
attributes.description: The ultimate goal is to understand how evolutionary pressures have shaped physiological systems among vertebrates and to determine the degree to which physiological systems can adapt/acclimate to natural and anthropogenic environmental changes.

attributes.label: Tawnee Milko
attributes.position: Manager, Climate & Sustainability Engagement

attributes.label: Curtis Suttle
attributes.position: Principal Investigator,The Suttle Lab, Departments of Earth and Ocean Sciences

attributes.label: Mark Johnson
attributes.position: Professor, Institute for Resources, Environment and Sustainability,Professor, Earth, Ocean and Atmospheric Sciences. Canada Research Chair, Ecohydrology. Coordinator, Agricultural Water Innovations in the Tropics.

attributes.label: Bernadette Mah
attributes.position: Program Manager, Peter Wall Institute for Advanced Studies

attributes.label: The Peter Wall Institute for Advanced Studies at UBC
attributes.description: The Peter Wall Institute for Advanced Studies brings together scholars from UBC and around the world to engage in deep and unconstrained research into some of the most profound questions and challenges facing humanity. The Institute facilitates collaboration between scholars of diverse backgrounds and seeks to create cohorts and communities of scholarship that stretch across both time and geographies.

attributes.label: Zero Waste Action Plan
attributes.description: The ZWAP2030 update will address barriers that have limited progress toward UBC’s zero waste goals to date, more strongly prioritize emissions reductions opportunities such as reuse, and reflect the important linkages with circular economy and UBC’s Climate Action Plan 2030.

attributes.label: Climate Solutions Showcase
attributes.description: Climate Solutions Showcase (CSS) features students, researchers, staff, and external partners working on justice-focused climate action, climate-related research and projects. CSS brings climate justice work to new audiences for knowledge mobilization and opportunities to establish connections for collaboration.

attributes.label: Forests and Communities in Transition (FACT)
attributes.description: Forests and Communities in Transition (FACT) includes the FACT Lab and the FACT Network. FACT is a University of British Columbia Faculty of Forestry initiative dedicated to research, dialogue and knowledge exchange. We aim to foster a global network of researchers and communities working in partnership with governments, non-government organizations, academia, industry and others to contribute to the development of more resilient and liveable forest-dependent communities.

attributes.label: UBC Responsible Investment Policy
attributes.description: The UBC endowment Responsible Investment Policy commits UBC to incorporate environmental, social, and governance (ESG) factors in its investment choices.

attributes.label: Social Innovation Research Theme
attributes.description: Social Innovation refers to new ideas that resolve existing social, cultural, economic and environmental challenges. A true social innovation is systems-changing – it permanently alters the perceptions, behaviours, relationships and structures that previously gave rise to these challenges.

attributes.label: Tara Ivanochko
attributes.position: Academic Director

attributes.label: Pelagic Ecosystems Lab
attributes.description: The Pelagic Ecosystems Laboratory – researching the structure and function of pelagic ecosystems and their coupling with climate, ocean and terrestrial systems.

attributes.label: Research Excellence Clusters 2022/23
attributes.description: Forty research excellence clusters led by researchers on the Vancouver campus will be funded through the Research Excellence Clusters initiative in 2022/23. These clusters are inter-departmental networks of researchers at UBC who collectively represent leaders in a particular field of study.

attributes.label: William Cheung
attributes.position: Associate Professor, UBC Institute of Resources, Environment and Sustainability

attributes.label: Lori Daniels
attributes.position: Professor, UBC Department of Forest and Conservation Resources

attributes.label: Sustainability Fellowships
attributes.description: Sustainability Fellowships are awarded to full-time faculty members who are leading the development or renewal of sustainability curriculum at UBC. Fellows meet up to share teaching and learning ideas, explore different teaching practices, learn from experts, and collaborate on projects, with support from UBC's Sustainability Hub. Previous Sustainability Fellows have developed the UBC framework for sustainability education, authored white papers, and piloted an introductory sustainability course.

attributes.label: Robert Kozak
attributes.position: Professor, Sustainable Buisness Management, UBC Department of Wood Science. Associate Dean, Academic UBC Faculty of Forestry

attributes.label: Megan Badri
attributes.position: Research Technician/Project lead, Urban Innovation Research

attributes.label: Environmental Policy Association
attributes.description: The UBC Environmental Policy Association (EPA) is UBC's first environmental group committed to analyzing economic and political responses to climate change. We run numerous events dedicated to engaging students of all backgrounds in local, federal, and global environmental policy through educational presentations and discussions.

attributes.label: Nidhi Sharma
attributes.position: Project Administrator

attributes.label: Environmental Law Group
attributes.description: The UBC Environmental Law Group (ELG) is a student-run club operating out of the Faculty of Law at UBC. We seek to connect students with environmental law and environmental justice issues. Our events provide opportunities for learning, activism, and fun. Our primary goal is to promote greater awareness of the legal aspects of current environmental problems.

attributes.label: Climate Teaching Connector
attributes.description: The UBC Climate Hub and the UBC Sustainability Initiative partnered to launch the Climate Teaching Connector (CTC), an innovative pilot project that delivers a more comprehensive integration of climate change and climate justice content throughout courses across UBC departments.

attributes.label: Climate Change Courses
attributes.description: Explore more than 600 courses at the undergraduate and graduate level that address climate, environmental, social and economic aspects of sustainability.

attributes.label: Beaty Biodiversity Museum
attributes.description: As Vancouver’s natural history museum, we invite you on a journey to discover the interconnectedness of all life on Earth, and our role in preserving these delicate systems. Through our collections, interactive activities and regularly changing art exhibitions, you can learn more about the biodiversity of British Columbia, Canada, and the world.

attributes.label: David Wilkinson
attributes.position:
Professor and Associate Head (External & Faculty)
Canadian Research Chair in Clean Energy and Electrochemical Technologies (Tier 1)

attributes.label: Water Action Plan
attributes.description: UBC is developing a Water Action Plan to build on our water conservation achievements to date and guide the University’s water management activities in the future.

attributes.label: Sprouts
attributes.description: Our story began in 1997 with the creation of the UBC Natural Food Co-op. In 2023, we operate as a volunteer run food co-operative with multiple programs that combat food insecurity on campus.

attributes.label: Forest Carbon Management Research
attributes.description: Supporting the contribution of BC’s forest sector to climate change mitigation while maximizing economic value and addressing adaptation. This project aims to increase the forestry sector’s carbon sink and storage potential through regionally customized forest management strategies that are responsive to climate change projections and support adaptation.  This project also demonstrates the GHG mitigation opportunities to substitute long-lived timber products for emission-intensive steel, concrete or plastics.

attributes.label: Biodiversity Research Centre
attributes.description: Biodiversity research aims to document the enormous diversity of life on earth and to identify the factors that generate and maintain this diversity.Scientists at UBC's Biodiversity Research Centre (BRC) investigate the ecology, evolution, and conservation of biological diversity through research at all levels, from genes to ecosystems through to interactions with society.

attributes.label: Greenest City Scholars
attributes.description: The Greenest City Scholars summer internship program sponsors 10 UBC graduate students to work on a sustainability project with the City of Vancouver. UBC graduate students are partnered with a city team and mentor to investigate and implement one of 10 projects identified under Vancouver’s Greenest City 2020 Action Plan.

attributes.label: Suzanne Simard
attributes.position: Professor, UBC Faculty of Forestry, Department of Forest and Conservation Sciences. Leader, The Mother Tree Project

attributes.label: Karen Taylor
attributes.position: Manager Sustainability Scholars Program

attributes.label: Indigenous Foundations
attributes.description: An information resource on key topics relating to the histories, politics, and cultures of the Aboriginal peoples of Canada. This website was developed to support students in their studies, and to provide instructors, researchers and the broader public with a place to begin exploring topics that relate to Aboriginal peoples, cultures, and histories. Indigenous Foundations was developed by the First Nations Studies Program at the University of British Columbia, located on the traditional, ancestral, and unceded territory of the Musqueam people.

attributes.label: Be Water Wise
attributes.description: The purpose of this campaign is to raise awareness of the sustainable choices students in UBC residences can make. When students work together to be Water Wise they will make a big impact in reducing UBC’s water and energy consumption.

attributes.label: Institute for Critical Indigenous Studies
attributes.description: This research and teaching institute is unique in North America for its structural commitment to Critical Indigenous Studies, a cognate discipline to Critical Ethnic Studies that is rooted in global Indigenous decolonial, feminist, and antiracist scholarship and politics. Its primary purpose is not cultural education, but rather the robust and ethical engagement of Indigenous political, methodological, and ideological concerns and conditions. Attention is given to the structures of and relationships between domains of knowledge and power, and the ways that experience informs knowledge across and between categories of difference. The commitments shaping CIS are therefore focused on empowering Indigenous peoples and transforming Indigenous-settler relationships through sophisticated and engaged, collaborative, and mutually respectful research and practice.

attributes.label: UBC School for Architecture and Landscape Architecture (SALA)
attributes.description: SALA is the school of architecture and landscape architecture at the University of British Columbia, located in Vancouver. Deeply committed to the quality of the built and natural environment, we are a close-knit community of scholars, designers, and makers brought together by a shared collaborative spirit.

attributes.label: Diana Lopez
attributes.position: Campus Living Lab Research Manager

attributes.label: John Richardson
attributes.position: Professor, UBC Faculty of Forestry

attributes.label: Oliver Lane
attributes.position: Manager Teaching and Learning

attributes.label: Guangyu Wang
attributes.position: Associate Dean, UBC Faculty of Forestry, Department of Forest Resources Management. Director, Asian Forest Research Centre

attributes.label: Forest Products Biotechnology and Bioenergy
attributes.description: Through innovation and insights, the FPB/B group will help decarbonise global society by replacing fossil-derived feedstocks with sustainable bioproducts. The group works on the technology, policy and life cycle analysis (LCA) aspects of decarbonising transport using the power of biotechnology.

attributes.label: Bud Fraser
attributes.position: Senior Planning and Sustainability Engineer

attributes.label: AdaptTree
attributes.description: The primary objective of this project is to improve provincial seed transfer policy and operational forest management response to climate change by comparing the adaptive portfolio of operational seedlots from tree breeding programs and seed orchards to the climatic distribution and landscape genomics of natural populations.

attributes.label: Sustaingineering
attributes.description: Sustaingineering has grown to be a one-of-a-kind multidisciplinary team. It consists of over 60 active members working on several fields, from designing a monitoring system for solar panels to developing an education program in hopes of enhancing youth’s interest in STEM and sustainability.

attributes.label: Mangrove Water Technologies
attributes.description: Mangrove Water Technologies converts carbon dioxide and saline waste-water into high value oil and gas field chemicals and re-usable water. Mangrove's technology reduces the volume of waste-water being injected into disposal wells, lowers transportation costs and provides reliability in the management and tracking of these elements of the waste stream.

attributes.label: Modeling glacier mass changes on regional and global scales
attributes.description: The objective of this NSERC DISCOVERY and CFI funded project is to develop and validate a physically based model of surface mass balance on a regional scale

attributes.label: Sustainable Agricultural Landscapes (SAL) Lab
attributes.description: The Sustainable Agricultural Landscapes (SAL) Lab conducts scientific research that contributes to understanding the ecology of, and management for, an agricultural system that meets current needs without compromising the needs of future generations. While sustainable agriculture should ensure that numerous needs are met, including those that are social and economic in nature, the SAL Lab focuses mainly on those related to the environment.

attributes.label: Omar Herrera
attributes.position: Program Manager, Transporation Futures, UBC Clean Energy Research Centre (CERC)

attributes.label: Angert Lab
attributes.description: Research in the Angert Lab lies at the interface of ecology and evolutionary biology. Much of our research focuses on the evolutionary ecology of species’ geographic distributions, asking what limits adaptation at the edges of species' ranges, why closely related species vary by orders of magnitude in range size, and how ranges are likely to shift in response to climatic changes.

attributes.label: Carole Jolly
attributes.position: Director, Community Development and Transportation

attributes.label: Styrofoam and Soft Plastics Recycling Program
attributes.description: Plastic bags (a type of soft plastic) and Styrofoam are NOT currently recyclable at UBC’s sort-it stations. If you are generating a significant amount of soft plastic or Styrofoam waste, you can participate in our pick-up program.

attributes.label: Pablo Akira Beimler
attributes.position: Co-Senior Project Manager

attributes.label: First Nations House of Learning
attributes.description: The First Nations House of Learning (FNHL) is based in the First Nations Longhouse. Its mandate is to make the University’s vast resources more accessible to Indigenous people and to improve its ability to meet their needs. It does this by organizing and maintaining Longhouse student services and spaces; overseeing public and academic programming at the Longhouse; leading and supporting strategic planning and communications on UBC Indigenous initiatives; and by providing a point of contact for Indigenous communities. It also engages with the public, media, and UBC personnel on a host of Indigenous-related matters.

attributes.label: Quantifying climate-dependent and anthropogenic impacts on ecosystem services in the Subarctic Pacific Ocean: State-of-the-art observational tools to inform policy and management
attributes.description: The project aims to establish a new generation of observational and modeling tools to quantify fisheries production and CO2 uptake capacity in the Subarctic Pacific Ocean. The main objective of this project is to understand the potential impacts of climate change and human induced disturbances on ecosystem dynamics, CO2 uptake capacity and fish biomass.

attributes.label: UBC Greenheart Tree Walk
attributes.description: Let Greenheart’s naturalists take you on a tour of the forest canopy. Learn about the diverse and unique ecosystems, sustainable eco-tourism, tree identification and First Nations’ cultural use of plants. Learn how trees are home to a multitude of woodland creatures such as the resident bald eagles, woodpeckers, hummingbirds and owls, and how forest plants are used as traditional medicines and food sources.

attributes.label: Climate Asset Map
attributes.description: The Climate Hub Climate Asset Map is a virtual online mapping project that seeks to identify, trace, connect and amplify climate action initiatives, projects, and program opportunities that are advancing climate action across the UBC campus and beyond.

attributes.label: The Mother Tree Project
attributes.description: NSERC Strategic Project Grant - Designing Successful Forest Renewal Practices for Our Changing Climate

attributes.label: Jon Garner
attributes.position: Communications and Engagement Manager

attributes.label: Tyler Harbottle
attributes.position: Senior Manager, Transit Government Relations

attributes.label: Chapman and Innovation Grants
attributes.description: The Chapman and Innovation Grants (C&I) offer UBC students the opportunity to create and carry out a meaningful project with a local not-for-profit community organization. C&I grants are designed to help students work with a community organization to test a new idea and take initiative in tackling an issue affecting underrepresented populations in their local communities.

attributes.label: Policy and Ecosystem Restoration in Fisheries (PERF)
attributes.description: Policy and Ecosystem Restoration in Fisheries (PERF) is a research group dedicated to restoring aquatic ecosystems and ensuring sustainable fisheries. By developing integrative research tools for historically-based restoration and ecosystem-based management, PERF aims to devise and evaluate sustainable fisheries policies.

attributes.label: UBC Botanical Garden
attributes.description: The original mission of the garden was research into the native flora of British Columbia. Over the past 100 years, the mission of UBC Botanical Garden has broadened to include education, research, conservation, community outreach, and public display of temperate plants from around the world.

attributes.label: FACT: Forests and Communities in Transition
attributes.description: Forests and Communities in Transition (FACT) includes the FACT Lab and the FACT Network. FACT is a University of British Columbia Faculty of Forestry initiative dedicated to research, dialogue and knowledge exchange. We aim to foster a global network of researchers and communities working in partnership with governments, non-government organizations, academia, industry and others to contribute to the development of more resilient and liveable forest-dependent communities.

attributes.label: George Hoberg
attributes.position: Professor, UBC School of Public Policy and Global Affairs

attributes.label: Michael White
attributes.position: Associate Vice-President, Campus and Community Planning

attributes.label: Kshamta Hunter
attributes.position: Manager of Sustainability Student Engagement

attributes.label: Rowan Waldron
attributes.position: Climate Action Planner

attributes.label: Transportation Futures
attributes.description: The goal of the Transportation Futures Network is to advance the field of transportaion and mobility towards a more sustainable, efficient, and equitable future. The network conducts research on a wide range of transportation-related topics, including urban planning, transportation policy, sustainable transportation systems, and new mobility technologies.

attributes.label: Medical Students for Climate Action
attributes.description: We are a team of medical students from the University of British Columbia Global Health Initiative Climate Health Team. We are passionate about learning and sharing the impacts of a changing climate on health. What started as a number of research projects has now grown into this website. We hope others can take advantage of this space, accessing and utilizing the knowledge we put together, to empower a more sustainable industry and better cared for populations.

attributes.label: Cool Tools Warm World
attributes.description: This research cluster focuses on design and testing of digital media to enhance learning and influence behaviour. Our cluster includes scholars in Climate Change Engagement, Education, Psychology, Visualization & Gaming. Working with partners in government, education and the technology industry, we explore how communities can be mobilized through new technologies and social practices to foster climate literacy and action.

attributes.label: Richard Price
attributes.position: Professor, Ubc Department of Political Science

attributes.label: Vice President Research and Innovation office
attributes.description: The Office of the Vice-President, Research and Innovation and its portfolio units help to coordinate and provide the environment to pursue world-leading impactful research. We work in partnership with our sister office at the Okanagan campus to provide UBC researchers with strategic information, resources, services and tools to support their work from writing grants through to generating impacts.

attributes.label: BioProducts Institute
attributes.description: The BioProducts Institute (BPI) is an innovative ecosystem of high-impact fundamental and applied researchers working on solutions to today’s climate and environmental challenges. BPI brings together inter- and multi-disciplinary researchers comprised of scientists, engineers, and market and policy experts to unlock the full potential of materials, chemicals and fuels produced in nature. Based on the guiding principles of circularity, sustainability and renewability, BPI seeks to reduce society’s footprint and tackle rampant environmental challenges such as reducing greenhouse gas emissions and plastic waste.

attributes.label: Natural Gas Secture at CERC
attributes.description: CERC aims to provide reliable evidence-based recommendations and technology solutions for the safe and environmentally responsible use of natural gas.

attributes.label: Campus Biodiversity Initiative: Research and Demonstration (CBIRD)
attributes.description: The Campus Biodiversity Initiative: Research and Demonstration (CBIRD) serves as an interdisciplinary and multi-stakeholder hub for connecting students, academics, practitioners and the wider community in collaborative applied research to advance scalable urban biodiversity ideas, policies and actions on campus. CBIRD is UBC’s platform for biodiversity partnership, enhancement, conservation and stewardship through applied research, community engagement, and the growth of a thriving biodiversity network.

attributes.label: Biometerology and Soil Physics Group
attributes.description: The UBC Biometeorology and Soil Physics Group studies the effects of climate variability and disturbance on the carbon and water cycles in forests, wetlands and agricultural fields in Western Canada. The main focus of our group is to better understand the micrometeorological and physiological processes controlling the exchange of carbon dioxide and other greenhouse gases (CH4, N2O), water vapor, and energy between terrestrial ecosystems and the atmosphere.

attributes.label: elementslab
attributes.description: elementslab is an applied urban design and environment research group in the School of Architecture + Landscape Architecture and the Centre for Interactive Research in Sustainability at the University of British Columbia. We emphasize meethods of measured visualization for urban design to elevate urban sustainability.

attributes.label: Centre for Sustainable Food Systems at UBC Farm
attributes.description: The Centre for Sustainable Food Systems at UBC Farm (CSFS) is a unique research centre and local to global Food Hub working towards a more sustainable, food secure future. Our living laboratory is committed to finding solutions to local and global challenges facing food systems sustainability.

attributes.label: GEOTRACES
attributes.description: GEOTRACES is an international programme which aims to improve the understanding of biogeochemical cycles and large-scale distribution of trace elements and their isotopes in the marine environment.

attributes.label: Student Environment Centre
attributes.description: The Student Environment Centre (SEC) is a resource group mandated by the University of British Columbia Alma Mater Society (UBC AMS) to provide environmental and sustainability resources for the UBC community. We are actively involved in organizing, promoting, and supporting various initiatives that critically examine the interactions between humans and the environment.

attributes.label: Kate Andrews
attributes.position: Green Labs and Energy Program Coordinator

attributes.label: Faculty of Land and Food Systems (LFS)
attributes.description: The Faculty of Land and Food Systems is a world leader in integrated research, education and service to address critical global issues around human health and a sustainable food supply. The UBC Faculty of Land and Food Systems uses student-centered learning to educate new generations of scientists equipped to solve the most fundamental issues faced by society — those focused around human health, a sustainable food supply and the responsible use of finite land and water resources. To that end, Faculty initiatives foster and support research excellence, innovative active learning environments, strong community connections, and global and local collaborations.

attributes.label: The Belowground Ecosystem Group
attributes.description: The primary goal of the Group is to conduct interdisciplinary collaborative research towards the scientific goal of linking structure and function in belowground ecosystems. Belowground ecology is recognized as one of the most critical and rapidly developing fields of ecology because it is still poorly understood. However, belowground ecology is vital to questions regarding the impacts of climate change, carbon sequestration, biodiversity, and sustainable management of forests and other ecosystems.

attributes.label: Daniel Pauly
attributes.position: UBC Killam Professor, Sea Around Us; Institute for the Oceans and Fisheries & Department of Zoology

attributes.label: Fuel Cells
attributes.description: British Columbia is a global leader in hydrogen and fuel cell research, development and commercialization in which the Clean Energy Research Centre has played a pivotal role. We present an electrochemical method for evaluating the wetted area under a droplet sitting on surface with mechanically induced roughness feature. The method takes advantage of the electrochemical double layer capacitance, which can be quantified using electrochemical approaches such as cyclic voltammetry

attributes.label: West Vancouver Residential Building Archetype Project
attributes.description: The West Vancouver Residential Building Archetypes project was conducted in collaboration with the District of West Vancouver and Boston Consulting. The purpose of the project was to examine and visualize alternative approaches for reducing energy demand and increasing renewable energy supply for residential homes in the District of West Vancouver.

attributes.label: Centre for Forest Conservation Genetics
attributes.description: Our lab investigates the population genetic structure of temperate and boreal trees, and the evolutionary dynamics that have resulted in that structure. We investigate the extent of local adaptation to climate in tree populations, and the capacity of those populations to adapt to new climates using common gardens and controlled environment experiments. Finally, our work is applied to guide genetic conservation and management strategies for our forests.

attributes.label: Ronald Kellett
attributes.position: Professor; Director, UBC School of Architecture and Landscape Architecture

attributes.label: Building Operations
attributes.description: UBC Facilities Group is responsible for facilities and utilities on the UBC Vancouver campus. The Groups’ seven departments manage the planning, development, operations and maintenance of areas like buildings, public spaces, landscaping, power, water, and heating on the Vancouver campus.

attributes.label: Vancouver Tree App
attributes.description: Vancouver Trees is a mobile app that describes commonly cultivated trees in the Metro Vancouver area. Users of the app can browse the extensive catalogue of nearly a thousand different trees, each one accurately described by its identification features, ecological needs and availability.

attributes.label: School of Population and Public Health
attributes.description: With a full range of academic programming paired with world-class research that bridges multiple disciplines, we are known as one of the best places in Canada for public and population health experts to train, learn and grow. We are committed to addressing the Truth and Reconciliation Commission of Canada Calls to Action, including work that supports the implementation of the UBC Indigenous Strategic Plan and the UBC Faculty of Medicine Response to the Truth and Reconciliation Commission of Canada Calls to Action.

attributes.label: Philipe Tortell
attributes.position: Professor, UBC Department of Earth, Ocean and Atmospheric Sciences

attributes.label: Environment and Community Research Stream, Department of Sociology
attributes.description: While the cluster maintains a core focus on environment and community, scholars in this area use their expertise to study a range of subjects including civic engagement in climate action and other social movements, the relationship between land use, community, and policymaking in urban centres and the nature of human-environment relationships.

attributes.label: Debbie Yeh
attributes.position: Manager, Community Programs and Outreach

attributes.label: John Madden
attributes.position: Director, Sustainability and Engineering

attributes.label: Green Building Action Plan
attributes.description: The GBAP outlines a holistic pathway for academic and residential buildings at the UBC Vancouver campus to advance towards making net positive contributions to human and natural systems by 2035. It plays a key role in pursuit of an exceptional built environment, one that will support the academic mission of teaching, learning and research and contribute to our sustainability goals on the academic campus and within residential neighbourhoods.

attributes.label: UBC Farm Markets
attributes.description: The Centre for Sustainable Food Systems at UBC Farm (CSFS) is a teaching and research centre and local-to-global food hub working towards a more sustainable, food-secure future.

attributes.label: Valentina Radic
attributes.position: Assistant Professor, UBC Department of Earth, Ocean and Atmospheric Sciences

attributes.label: Natalie Hawryshkewich
attributes.position: Communications and Engagement Specialist

attributes.label: UBC Building Operations
attributes.description: Our work includes maintaining and operating our lands, buildings, and fleet as sustainably as possible for the lowest total cost of ownership... Among some of the many daily functions members of our team perform, we keep spaces lit, the air temperature comfortable, waste sorted and recycled, and our campus clean.

attributes.label: Dan Moore
attributes.position: Professor, UBC Department of Geography. Forest Renewal Chair of Forest Hydrology

attributes.label: SEEDS Sustainability Program
attributes.description: The SEEDS Sustainability Program advances campus sustainability by creating partnerships between students, operational staff, and faculty on innovative and impactful research projects.

attributes.label: Roger Francois
attributes.position: Professor, Department of Earth, Ocean and Atmospheric Sciences

attributes.label: X̱wi7x̱wa Library
attributes.description: Xwi7xwa Library is a centre for academic and community Indigenous scholarship. Its collections and services reflect Aboriginal approaches to teaching, learning, and research. Everyone is welcome to visit Xwi7xwa Library.

attributes.label: 20-Year Sustainability Strategy
attributes.description: The 20-year Sustainability Strategy for UBC's Vancouver campus provides a long-term strategic direction for sustainability across teaching, learning and research, operations and infrastructure and the community.

attributes.label: Common Energy
attributes.description: Common Energy UBC is the largest and most active student-run sustainability organization on campus. We are made up of diverse individuals working to incorporate sustainability into all aspects of the UBC community. We aim to affect real change by building strong networks and working proactively with the University. We strive to foster leadership and engage our peers through innovative programming.

attributes.label: Adam Hyslop
attributes.position: Manager, Transportation Planning

attributes.label: University Neighbourhood's Association
attributes.description: The University Neighbourhoods Association (UNA) oversees the major residential neighbourhoods around UBC’s campus: Chancellor Place, East Campus, Hampton Place, Hawthorn Place, Wesbrook Place, and other designated buildings as stipulated in the Neighbours Agreement 2020.  The purpose of the UNA is set out in its Constitution and Bylaws. It manages infrastructure, such as street and sidewalk repairs, and regulates matters of concern in the public realm, such as parking and noise.

attributes.label: The Harley Lab - Coastal Marine Ecology
Transportation Infrastructure and Public Space (TIPSlab)
attributes.description: The Transportation Infrastructure and Public Space (TIPSlab) is an interdisciplinary research group which examines the potential and implications of future transportation infrastructure. TIPSlab aims to integrate social and ecological concerns into emerging design methodologies.

attributes.label: Alejandra Urcelay
attributes.position: Data Manager

attributes.label: Transportation Plan
attributes.description: The UBC Transportation Plan outlines the direction of transportation goals, policies and projects on the ground at UBC. This Plan also commits to actions aimed at improving the experience getting around campus.

attributes.label: ArcTrain
attributes.description: The international program "Processes and impacts of climate change in the North Atlantic Ocean and the Canadian Arctic" (ArcTrain) is a Collaborative Research and Training Experience Program(CREATE) of the Natural Sciences and Engineering Research Council of Canada (NSERC). It aims to train a new generation of scientists in geosciences, biology, physics and chemistry for addressing complex issues related to climate change in the Arctic and subarctic regions.

attributes.label: Katherine Came
attributes.position: Communications Manager for UBC Institute of Oceans and Fisheries

attributes.label: Behavioural Sustainability Lab
attributes.description: We use psychological principles and insights to design behavioral solutions to solve financial and environmental sustainability challenges. We do so by running field and lab experiments to promote behavior change in resource conservation, waste reduction, climate mitigation, and financial independence.

attributes.label: Sea Around Us
attributes.description: The Sea Around Us is a research initiative (located at the Institute for the Oceans and Fisheries, formerly Fisheries Centre) that assesses the impact of fisheries on the marine ecosystems of the world, and offers mitigating solutions to a range of stakeholders.

attributes.label: Ethnographic Film Unit
attributes.description: We use the language of documentary video to explore issues of environmentally and socially responsible resource use that prioritizes collaborative community-based practise. The videos are an active research tool; a catalyst for conversation and for deeper enquiry. They are also end products - broadcast-quality videos for use in highschool and university classrooms, conferences, workshops, and film festivals.

attributes.label: Acdaemic District Energy System
attributes.description: UBC continues to provide reliable, cost-effective, and increasingly sustainable utilities to its campus and broader community.  Three milestone projects helped UBC achieve a 34 per cent greenhouse gas (GHG) emission reduction in 2016 from 2007 levels. Looking ahead to 2020, UBC will be tripling the capacity of its biomass plant, energizing 70% of the ADES with clean waste wood, saving an additional $1.0 million annually and drastically reducing greenhouse gas emissions.

attributes.label: Cait Murphy
attributes.position: Engagement Specialist Regional & International Engagement

attributes.label: UBC Department of Zoology
attributes.description: Zoology as an official department started in 1924 and has expanded to become one of the strongest and most broadly-based life science departments in the country, with a scope that spans from molecules to cells, whole organisms, populations, and communities. The Department’s research and educational program is highly productive and influential. Our department expertise includes Fellows of the Royal Society of London, Members of the US National Academy of Sciences, Fellows of the Royal Society of Canada, Canada Research Chairs and a Canada 150 chair.

attributes.label: Sustainable Development of Hydrogen Fuel Supply Chain
attributes.description: New technology penetration into the transportation system requires a balance between the vehicle growth and supply chain development. However, sufficient initial fueling or charging network coverage needs to be created well in advance of vehicle rollout. Considering the significant capital investment which will be followed by a long period of underutilization, the new supply chain will face a long period of negative cash flow. This research aims to design a methodological framework for the sustainable development of the hydrogen supply chain (HSC) in British Columbia for a 30 year time frame.

attributes.label: Environmental Sciences Student Association (ESSA)
attributes.description: The Environmental Sciences Students' Association (ESSA) is a student club representing the environmental science program at UBC. We are dedicated to bringing together people with a passion for the environment. We organize social events for students to get to know each other outside the classroom and put on academic conferences and discussions with professionals in the environmental sciences field, as well as study groups for the program’s core courses. We also take part in events promoting public awareness of environmental issues.

attributes.label: Climate Change Accountability Reports
attributes.description: These reports, required under the province's carbon neutral regulation, track UBC's actions and progress towards carbon neutrality and achieving the goals of UBC's Climate Action Plan.

attributes.label: Hisham Zerriffi
attributes.position: Associate Professor, UBC Faculty of Forestry, Department of Forest Resource Management

attributes.label: Stephen Sheppard
attributes.position: Professor, UBC Faculty of Forestry, Departmentof Forest Resource Management, Director, Collaborative for Advanced Landscape Planning

attributes.label: ArcticNet
attributes.description: ArcticNet is a Network of Centres of Excellence of Canada that brings together scientists, engineers, and other professionals in the human health, natural and social sciences with partners from Inuit organizations, northern communities, federal and provincial agencies and the private sector to study the impacts of climate and socio-economic change in the Canadian North.

attributes.label: UBC Botanical Gardens Plant Collections
attributes.description: UBC Botanical Garden curates a collection of some 40,000 accessioned plants representing approximately 5,000 taxa from temperate regions around the world. Temperate forest plants of British Columbia, eastern North America and Asia are curated in woodland gardens and a classic alpine garden displays the diverse flora of high-altitude regions of the world.

attributes.label: Transportation Futures Project
attributes.description: Transportation Futures in British Columbia is a five-year, interdisciplinary research project supported by the Pacific Institute for Climate Solutions (PICS) and hosted by UBC. As a research-intensive university, UBC’s unique, low-emissions campus can act as a city-scale test bed for clean, safe and connected transportation.

attributes.label: Michael Lipsen
attributes.position: Lecturer, UBC Department of Earth, Ocean and Atmospheric Sciences

attributes.label: HOPR Bike Share Program
attributes.description: HOPR is operating at UBC under a License Agreement with the University that lays out various legal, financial and operational requirements, including where and how HOPR bikes are used on campus. Over 80 designated bike share hubs have been installed across campus to make it easier for users to locate and park shared bikes, conserving bike rack space for other cyclists.

attributes.label: Fisheries Economics Research Unit (FERU)
attributes.description: Based out of the Institute for the Oceans and Fisheries at the University of British Columbia, the Fisheries Economics Research Unit strives for interdisciplinary solutions to global, national, and local marine and freshwater management issues. We focus on economic and policy analysis and mobilize researchers, students, and practitioners to advance resource management for the benefit of current and future generations, while maintaining ‘healthy’ ecosystems.

attributes.label: Indigenous Legal Studies Program
attributes.description: With strong support from faculty members, staff, and students associated with Indigenous Legal Studies, the Allard School of Law recruits and supports Indigenous law students, offers courses in Aboriginal and Indigenous law, conducts research often in partnership with Indigenous peoples and nations, provides legal assistance to Indigenous peoples through the Indigenous Community Legal Clinic in the Downtown Eastside, and generally fosters a greater understanding of the place of Indigenous peoples in Canadian society and abroad.

attributes.label: Kathryn Harrison
attributes.position: Professor, UBC Department of Political Science

attributes.label: Mark Martinez
attributes.position: Professor, Department of Chemical and Biological Engineering. Director, UBC Pulp and Paper Centre (PPC), Advanced Papermaking Intiative (API) and MEL Green Bio-Products

attributes.label: ForLives: Forests and Livelihoods for Sustainable Development
attributes.description: The global sustainable development goals (SDGs) cannot be achieved without protecting forests, and forests cannot be adequately protected without engaging and supporting the millions of Indigenous and rural people living near them. Our ForLives cluster aims to address the lack of data on the contribution that forests can and do make to the SDGs by engaging with partner organizations and Indigenous and local communities on targeted research that tackles multiple SDGs simultaneously.

attributes.label: UBC Department of Earth, Ocean and Atmospheric Sciences (EOSC)
attributes.description: The research of the department spans studies of the earth's deep interior, near-surface geology, the environment, Earth's oceans & atmosphere, and other terrestrial planets. Rich collaboration both internal and external to the department study the complex interactions in Earth systems and provide access to outstanding instrumentation and expertise. EOAS maintains active ties with industry partners, consulting firms and government labs.

attributes.label: Peter Arcese
attributes.position: Professor, UBC Faculty of Forestry, Forest and Conservation Sciences, Forest Renewal BC Chair in Conservation Biology

attributes.label: Hadi Dowlatabadi
attributes.position: Professor, Liu Institute for Global Issues, Institute for Resources, Environment and Sustainability. Canada Research Chair (t1, Applied Mathematics of Global Change)

attributes.label: School of Public Policy and Global Affairs
attributes.description: The UBC School of Public Policy and Global Affairs (SPPGA) integrates world-class scholarship, teaching, research, and policy engagement to contribute towards positive change.

attributes.label: Alma Mater Society (AMS)
attributes.description: The AMS is UBC Vancouver’s Student Union and since 1915 we’ve been holding UBC and government accountable to you – the students. We believe that when students thrive, everyone wins – UBC wins, society wins and most importantly YOU WIN!

attributes.label: Bio Energy Research and Demonstration Facility
attributes.description: The Bioenergy Research and Demonstration Facility (BRDF) is an energy generation facility that processes renewable biomass sourced from urban wood waste to generate thermal energy for heating campus buildings. A first of its kind project in North America, the system reduces UBC’s reliance on fossil fuels, provides a quarter of campus heating needs, and eliminates 14% of campus greenhouse gas emissions.

attributes.label: Energy and Water Services
attributes.description: Established in 2014, the unit was created as a dedicated centre of energy and utility expertise at UBC. Its mission is to generate, distribute and conserve the Vancouver campus’ energy and water resources in an open and transparent manner that maintains environmental comfort, ensures system reliability, minimizes life cycle cost, reduces GHG emissions, and seeks out innovative solutions.

attributes.label: Milind Kandlikar
attributes.position: Professor and Director, UBC Institute for Resources, Environment and Sustainability. Professor, Liu Institute for Global Issues

attributes.label: Sustainable Forest Management Research Group (SFMRG)
attributes.description: The Sustainable Forest Management Research Group (SFMRG) was established in 2000 to foster innovative research on various topics related to sustainable forestry throughout the world. All aspects of management are considered, ranging from ecological to social and economic issues. The interdisciplinary nature of our research allows individuals to pursue their interests while benefiting from a variety of insights and perspectives. This depth contributes to the quality of our collaborative work as well.

attributes.label: First Nations and Indigenous Studies
attributes.description: First Nations and Indigenous Studies (FNIS) was founded in 2001 to provide students with an understanding of the histories, contemporary realities, and political concerns of Indigenous peoples in Canada and beyond. As an interdisciplinary undergraduate program within the Faculty of Arts, FNIS reflects the belief that deep understanding and ethical engagement are central to the wellbeing of resurgent Indigenous communities and foundational to more respectful Indigenous-settler relations.

attributes.label: Community Energy and Emissions Plan
attributes.description: Since UBC’s population is expected to continue growing to approximately 24,000 residents by 2041, we’ve developed a Community Energy and Emissions Plan as a comprehensive framework to address these issues.

attributes.label: Sean Smukler
attributes.position: Assistant professor, Faculty of Land and Food Systems

attributes.label: Campus Energy Centre
attributes.description: The Campus Energy Centre (CEC) is UBC’s $24 million state-of-the-art hot water boiler facility. Located in the heart of our 1,000 acre campus, the facility is capable of meeting all of UBC’s heating requirements. The CEC is the primary energy source for our new hot water district energy system.

attributes.label: Evgeny Pakhomov
attributes.position: Professor, Department of Earth, Ocean and Atmospheric Sciences. Director, UBC Institute for the Oceans and Fisheries

attributes.label: Smart Cities
attributes.description: The Smart City is an integrated approach to improving efficiency, growing the local economy, achieving environmental sustainability and improving the quality of life for citizens.

attributes.label: BiRNet (Bioinnovative Renewables Network)
attributes.description: The Bio-innovative Renewables Network (BiRNet) aims to align and lead Canada’s applied research efforts to create a cost-competitive bio-economy focused on renewable and recyclable products derived from Canada’s abundant and sustainable forestry and agricultural natural resources.

attributes.label: Patrick Condon
attributes.position: Professor, UBC School of Architecture and Landscape Architecture, Urban Design Program

attributes.label: Angelique Pilon
attributes.position: Director, Urban Innovation Research Group

attributes.label: Applied Freshwater Ecology Research Unit (AFERU)
attributes.description: This group is interested in applied conservation and management issues as they pertain to British Columbia’s freshwater resources. The group consists of research scientists and staff from both the BC Ministry of Environment and Climate Change Strategy (Conservation Science Section) and the Freshwater Fisheries Society of BC. Its core members and students focus on recreational fisheries management, stocking and aquaculture, recreational fisheries marketing, minimum instream flow to support fish production, species at risk and whole system nitrification and monitoring.

attributes.label: Liska Richer
attributes.position: Manager, SEEDS Program

attributes.label: Sumeet Gulati
attributes.position: Professor, UBC Faculty of Land and Food Systems, Environmental and Resource Economics

attributes.label: Pacific Institute for Climate Solutions
attributes.description: The Pacific Institute for Climate Solutions is a research and engagement network across four collaborating research universities – University of British Columbia, University of Victoria, Simon Fraser University, and University of Northern British Columbia. PICS supports the cogeneration of climate solutions research that can be actively used by decision-makers to develop effective mitigation and adaptation policies and actions in BC and beyond.

attributes.label: Landscape Ecology Lab
attributes.description: Our lab is unified by a curiosity of understanding the impact of human activities on landscape dynamics. We are interested in the implications of landscape change on ecological processes as well as on the ecosystem services on which society depends. Depending on the question at hand, our research uses fieldwork, historical aerial photography, modelling, satellite imagery, and interview techniques. We collaborate with managers, First Nations, and other local people who live and depend on the landscapes in which we work.

attributes.label: Simon Donner
attributes.position: Associate Professor, UBC Department of Geography

attributes.label: Meghan Wise
attributes.position: Coordinator

attributes.label: Department of Chemical and Biological Engineering (CHBE)
attributes.description: To educate and conduct research to serve the people of BC and the world in an environment that fosters research breakthroughs and teaching innovations, and supports students, faculty and staff to succeed. The Department of Chemical and Biological Engineering is committed to providing outstanding programs and empowering engineers with excellent technical and leadership skills, integrity, and social responsibility. We recognize the importance of creating novel and sustainable solutions to serve public interests and to address global challenges in areas such as health, energy, and environment.

attributes.label: Climate Justice Research Collaborative
attributes.description: The CJRC is a unique opportunity for undergraduate students to collaborate on interdisciplinary research projects focused on climate change and climate justice. These projects are undertaken with the supervision of faculty and the mentorship of graduate students. Students receive course credit for their participation.

attributes.label: Master of Engineering Leadership: Clean Energy Engineering
attributes.description: The Master of Engineering Leadership (MEL) in Clean Energy Engineering is a professional degree for engineers who want to excel and drive innovation in the field of clean energy. This hybrid master’s program combines graduate-level engineering courses with UBC Sauder’s Robert H. Lee Graduate School courses – giving you the skills and confidence to take your career in new directions.

attributes.label: Hannah Wittman
attributes.position: Academic Director, UBC Centre for Sustainable Food Systems. Professor, UBC Faculty of Land and Food Systems. Professor, UBC Institute for Environment, Resources and Sustainability.

attributes.label: Sara Muir-Owen
attributes.position: PICS UBC Campus Coordinator

attributes.label: Liu Institute for Global Issues
attributes.description: The Liu Institute for Global Issues is an interdisciplinary research hub that aspires to influence academic and public debates about global issues, inform policy decisions, and become an important source of ideas, education, information and perspectives.

attributes.label: Green Labs Program
attributes.description: The Green Labs Program supports researchers to reduce the environmental impact of laboratory-based activities by implementing sustainable practices and technologies. We provide UBC faculty, staff and students with the opportunity to learn about wise environmental practices, exchange ideas, and access recycling and energy conservation programs.

attributes.label: Youth Climate Ambassador Project
attributes.description: Created in response to the demand for climate change narratives that focus on hope and action rather than doom and gloom, YCAP offers free climate justice workshops supported by the UBC Climate Hub in partnership with Be The Change Earth Alliance. YCAP connects trained university student facilitators with high school classes and community groups, creating opportunities for peer-to-peer storytelling centred around climate justice, systems change, and community resistance.

attributes.label: Advanced Propulsion
attributes.description: The Clean Energy Research Centre (CERC) hosts one of the leading global research efforts on natural gas engines focusing on the clean burning potential in stationary and mobile applications.

attributes.label: Training Our Future Ocean Leaders (Ocean Leaders)
attributes.description: Training Our Future Ocean Leaders (Ocean Leaders) is an innovative new UBC program that aims to prepare the next generation of interdisciplinary marine researchers with the ability to translate technical knowledge into policy and management innovations for the oceans.

attributes.label: First Nations Development Research Theme
attributes.description: First Nations possess an abundance of human capacity, natural resources and cultural heritage. These assets provide the foundation on which lively and sustainable communities are built. By leveraging these assets, First Nations can develop and maintain thriving economies while preserving local culture.

attributes.label: Global Fisheries Cluster (Global-FC)
attributes.description: Marine fish and invertebrate stocks are a vital component of the world’s social-ecological system, contributing significantly to the well-being of human society. Issues pertaining to marine fisheries sustainability have become a global challenge, with direct implications for biodiversity, food security and public health.  Research to help tackle this problem requires a global focus and global data infrastructure, strong interdisciplinary collaboration between the natural and social sciences, and empirical and theoretical studies that generate knowledge aimed specifically at informing public policy.

attributes.label: Rashid Sumaila
attributes.position: Professor, UBC Institute for the Oceans and Fisheries

attributes.label: FRESH (Forest Resources and Environmental Services Hub)
attributes.description: Researchers and students in FRESH are working on all aspects related to the sustainable management of forests and natural resources, including ecology, economics, and social considerations.

attributes.label: Centre for Social Innovation and Impact Investing (SauderS3i)
attributes.description: The Centre for Social Innovation & Impact Investing (SauderS3i) is focused on leveraging business tools to advance social innovation and sustainability, through research, incubation, and application. SauderS3i defines social innovation as a new approach which fosters initiatives that contribute to solving existing social, cultural, economic, political, and environmental challenges.

attributes.label: Aviva Savelson
attributes.position: Senior Manager, Public Engagement

attributes.label: Daniel Mosquin
attributes.position: Research Manager, UBC Botanical Gardens

attributes.label: BRITE (Biodiversity Research: Training and Education) Program
attributes.description: The Biodiversity Research Centre (BRC) at the University of British Columbia is pleased to host BRITE (Biodiversity Research: Training and Education), a training program aimed at widening opportunities and skill sets among our students and post-doctoral fellows.

attributes.label: Japan Foundation Nereus Program
attributes.description: The Nippon Foundation Nereus Program is a global partnership of 17 leading institutes working to advance our comprehensive understanding of the global human-ocean system across the natural and social sciences. Our research spans from oceanography and marine ecology to fisheries economics and impacts on coastal communities. We pursue sustainability in a way that observes the location, identity, context, and history of the communities we work with as diversities to be embraced rather than differences to be overcome.

attributes.label: Penny Martyn
attributes.position: Manager

attributes.label: John Innes
attributes.position: Dean, UBC Faculty of Forestry, Forest Renewal BC Chair in Forest Management

attributes.label: UBC Map the System
attributes.description: Map the System is a global research-based competition that asks you to think differently about social or environmental change. Participants select a social or environmental issue, conduct research, and present the issue in a way that people can share and learn from.

attributes.label: Campus and Community Planning
attributes.description: A team of experts in sustainability, planning, design, engagement, and community building dedicated to building a vibrant and sustainable community for everyone who studies, works, lives and creates at UBC. We actively engage with Musqueam, students, faculty, staff, residents and visitors to UBC.  Together with the campus community, we are striving to make the world a better place: the heart of our academic mission. We are committed to careful planning, informed consultation and coordination.

attributes.label: Amber Heckelman
attributes.position: PhD Student, UBC Land and Food Systems, Liu Scholar

attributes.label: David Tindall
attributes.position: Professor, UBC Department of Sociology

attributes.label: Sustainability Hub
attributes.description: UBC has committed to the integration of our operational and academic efforts in sustainability and the Sustainability Hub, established in 2010, is the University’s agent in this innovation. It fosters partnerships and collaborations that extend beyond traditional boundaries of disciplines, sectors and geographies to address the critical issues of our time. The Hub's work is carried out under two cross-cutting themes: Campus as a Living Laboratory and the University as an agent of change.

attributes.label: School of Community and Regional Planning
attributes.description: SCARP's mission is to advance the transition to sustainability through excellence in integrated policy and planning research, professional education, and community service. SCARP is committed to generating and transforming knowledge into action by planning in partnership to improve lives and communities and the quality of built and natural environments.

attributes.label: Engineers for a Sustainable World
attributes.description: Formerly known as the CHBE Sustainability Club, Engineers for a Sustainable World (ESW) UBC is affiliated with ESW USA and the associated student chapters. ESW-UBC is the only non-US chapter of ESW. Our mission is to forge innovative, lasting solutions to local and global sustainability challenges. We design and implement sustainable projects through our student and professional chapters.  We educate and train individuals and organizations on sustainable policies and practices and build a global network of communities with a shared culture of sustainability.

attributes.label: Clean Energy Research Centre
attributes.description: The Clean Energy Research Centre (CERC) is a multidisciplinary research hub dedicated to undertaking world-class clean-energy research, training, development and demonstrations. Our goal is to become a world leader and a research–development–demonstration powerhouse for innovative clean-energy solutions to climate change and sustainability problems.

attributes.label: Adaptation of Asia-Pacific Forests to Climate Change
attributes.description: The goal of this project is to address this uncertainty and help forest managers and policy makers to develop effective management strategies to maintain resilient forest ecosystems for adaptation to climate change.

attributes.label: AMS Sustainability Projects Fund
attributes.description: The AMS Sustainability Projects Fund (SPF) was established in September 2011 when UBC students passed a successful referendum to support student-led sustainability projects through the Lighter Footprint Fee. In 2022, this fee was renamed to the Climate Action Fee in which students pay $1.50 every year towards projects that encourage environmental, social and economic sustainability within the UBC community.

attributes.label: Sustainable Purchasing Guide
attributes.description: This guide has been designed to help you, as a staff and faculty member or student, to purchase sustainable goods and services. It supports the adoption of UBC Financial Operations' Sustainable Purchasing Priorities and reflects a triple-bottom-line approach that balances best value, social equity and environmental protection.

attributes.label: Stepan Wood
attributes.position: Professor, Peter A. Allard School of Law

attributes.label: Institute for the Oceans and Fisheries
attributes.description: The UBC Institute for the Oceans and Fisheries (IOF) contributes to a transformative global shift toward sustainable coastal ecosystems, oceans and fisheries. It brings together a community of Canadian and international experts in ocean and freshwater species, systems, economics, and issues—and provides new insights into how our marine systems function, and the impacts of human activity on those systems.

attributes.label: Walter Merida
attributes.position: Professor, UBC Department of Mechanical Engineering. Director, UBC Clean Energy Research Centre (CERC)

attributes.label: Green Labs Fund
attributes.description: In the four years prior to launch, UBC’s utility costs had doubled as a result of climbing energy prices. The project goal was to reduce energy and water consumption in core academic buildings, along with associated greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions, thereby reducing the University’s energy costs.

attributes.label: Sara Harris
attributes.position: Professor of Teaching, UBC Department of Earth, Ocean and Atmospheric Sciences

attributes.label: Geophysical Disaster Computational Fluid Dynamics Centre
attributes.description: The Geophysical Disaster Computational Fluid Dynamics Centre (GeoDisaster Centre) at the University of British Columbia (UBC) studies weather-related and other natural disasters, with an ultimate goal of enhancing the Canadian economy and saving lives.

attributes.label: Department of Forest and Conservation Sciences
Marine Mammal Research Unit (MMRU)
attributes.description: The Marine Mammal Research Unit (MMRU) is integrated within the Institute for the Oceans and Fisheries and works with other departments and institutions, combining specialties in a coordinated effort to provide independent research and advice on matters related to marine mammals. Members investigate interactions between humans and marine mammals, marine mammals as indicators of ecosystem change, and the natural history, biology and conservation of marine mammals.

attributes.label: Department of Geography
attributes.description: UBC Geography is one of the top geography departments in the world. Through our research and teaching, we strive for a critical and ethical approach to the natural environment and society’s relationship with it.

attributes.label: Indigenous/Science at UBC
attributes.description: Our research cluster seeks to catalyze a conversation about science, with specific application to understanding Indigenous history and the environment via both empirical evidence and critical social theory. Our focus includes the Indigenous past, its material and historical manifestations, the environmental context within which it occurred, and the study of this past. Our work is interdisciplinary and ovelaps with Indigenous studies, geochemistry, philosophy, archaeology, history, legal studies, anthropology, and museology.

attributes.label: Rebecca Monnerat
attributes.position: Project Manager, Liu Institute

attributes.label: Converting Wastewater and Carbon Dioxide Into Value
attributes.description: The technology is a waste-to-value innovation that converts waste carbon dioxide and high salinity waste-water into value added chemicals and desalinated water for re-use.

attributes.label: Nadia Joe
attributes.position: Co-Senior Project Manager

attributes.label: Gerry McGeough
attributes.position: Director, Planning and Design

attributes.label: Connecting Human And Natural Systems (CHANS) Lab
attributes.description: Our mission is to conduct cutting-edge analysis and modelling of social-ecological systems, for both fundamental insight and application to real-world practice and transformation–to enable the just treatment of current and future people and the natural world.

attributes.label: Tree Ring Lab
attributes.description: We are an interdisciplinary group of researchers dedicated to transformative research on modern environmental challenges with widespread societal implications, including megafires and forest dieback. Through our work, we aim to enact meaningful change in forest management and governance through collaborations with Indigenous and local communities, government agencies, and the forest industry.

attributes.label: Sustainable Forest Management Network
attributes.description: The Network started from a foundation of researchers from a range of disciplines working with partners from industry, universities, government, Aboriginal peoples and non-governmental organizations to explore the very foundations of sustainable forest management. Through rigorous scientific peer-reviewed research, Network partners and researchers are discovering new solutions to some of the most perplexing challenges facing Canada’s forests today.

attributes.label: Land Use Plan
attributes.description: UBC's Land Use Plan sets the long-term direction for land use and transportation. The provincial government approves UBC's Land Use Plan. The vision is for a compact, complete community that provides daily needs within walking distance and a university community that integrates academic, neighbourhood and natural spaces while respecting its neighbours.

attributes.label: Chris Harley
attributes.position: Associate Professor, UBC Department of Zoology

attributes.label: Centre for Law and the Environment
attributes.description: The Centre for Law and the Environment (CLE) is a hub at Allard Law for creating and spreading knowledge, ideas and practices about the role of law in securing a healthy environment and a sustainable society.

attributes.label: Forests and Oceans for the Future
attributes.description: Forests and Oceans for the Future is a research group based at UBC that focuses on ecological knowledge research conducted in collaboration with north coast British Columbia communities. Our research is intended to help incorporate core community values and knowledge (aboriginal and non-aboriginal) in local sustainable forest and natural resource management.

attributes.label: Campus Energy Centre
attributes.description: The CEC is part of UBC’s greenhouse gas (GHG) emission reduction program. Through the CEC’s high-efficiency energy production and our new district energy system and specialized underground piping, we will reduce UBC’s annual carbon dioxide (CO2) footprint by an expected 22 per cent from 2007 baseline levels.

attributes.label: Energy Planning and Innovation (EPI)
attributes.description: The Energy Planning and Innovation (EPI) group operates within UBC’s Energy and Water Services (EWS). The group’s mandate is to develop long-range energy infrastructure plans and implement energy and water conservation and efficiency measures that reduce UBC’s operating costs, defer costly infrastructure upgrades, reduce greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions and lessen UBC’s exposure to fluctuating energy markets.

attributes.label: SEEDS Sustainability Library
attributes.description: The SEEDS Sustainability Library is a comprehensive repository of applied research and knowledge. It’s a key tool for decision makers. Open access applied research reports contribute to a body of knowledge, learning and action to ignite sustainability ideas, policies and practices, and enable the broader community to learn, apply and build on previous research.

attributes.label: Decision Insights for Buisness and Society (DIBS)
attributes.description: This is the mission of Decision Insights for Business and Society (DIBS): A Centre for Behavioural Research and Policy Solutions at the UBC Sauder School of Business. DIBS will develop and share insights into why and how people make decisions and improve organizational strategies for addressing social, environmental, political, and economic challenges.

attributes.label: Soil, Water and Sustainability Group
attributes.description: The Soil, Water and Sustainability Research Group is a collective of collaborating academics, students and professionals whose research addresses the basic scientific information required for food production, forest products and maintaining the integrity of ecological systems for sustaining the resource base. The focus is on the physical and biological environment and the integrated relationship between land and water systems.

attributes.label: PlugShare
attributes.description: The use of more electric vehicles reduces not only carbon dioxide emissions but also the gasoline and fossil-fuel powered vehicles on campus. UBC hopes that providing this infrastructure for the community will encourage students, academics, and residents to go electric.

attributes.label: Grace Nosek
attributes.position: Climate Hub Founder

attributes.label: Stephanie Waterman
attributes.position: Associate Professor, UBC Department of Earth, Ocean and Atmospheric Sciences

attributes.label: Karen Bakker
attributes.position: Professor, UBC Department of Geography. Canada Research Chair in Political Ecology. Director, UBC Program on Water Governance

attributes.label: Climate Wellbeing Engagement Network
attributes.description: The Climate Wellbeing Engagement Network is a student-led initiative focusing on developing and connecting students, staff, faculty and the broader community to a network of climate distress and wellbeing workshops, resources, community engagement and learning opportunities.

attributes.label: Integrated Stormwater Management Plan (ISMP)
attributes.description: ISMP was created to ensure that the campus is responding to the ecological needs of the local lands while protecting the Point Grey cliffs and the valued areas of the campus from flooding. Stormwater management is required for all new development projects on the UBC campus. The Integrated Stormwater Mangement Plan (ISMP) is guided by the performance requirements for stormwater management in the Vancouver Campus Plan, Technical Guidelines, Neighbourhood Plans and the Green Building Action Plan.

attributes.label: Tim Herron
attributes.position: CIRS Events and Engagement Manager

attributes.label: Program on Water Governance (PoWG)
attributes.description: The Program on Water Governance (PoWG) conducts cutting-edge interdisciplinary research on water sustainability, and fosters dialogue on water policy with communities and decision-makers. In addition to our journal publications, we engage in extensive public outreach activities, through briefing notes, policy papers, and a renewed web presence, which makes extensive water-related information resources freely available. The PoWG team also advises national and international agencies, including (recently) the National Round Table on Environment and Economy, the United Nations Office of the High Commissioner for Human Rights, Environment Canada, and the BC Ministry of the Environment.

attributes.label: Janeen Alliston
attributes.position: Director, Communications of Transit Projects

attributes.label: David Cohen
attributes.position: Professor Emeritus, UBC Faculty of Forestry

attributes.label: Climate Hub
attributes.description: The UBC Climate Hub is a student-led, staff-supported initiative that aims to connect and empower university and community stakeholders to take bold climate action for a just future. We believe UBC can help facilitate the transformational social change needed to address the climate crisis. Collectively, we can shape UBC's climate emergency response.

attributes.label: Energy Management
attributes.description: UBC’s efforts to manage our energy consumption addresses the triple bottom line of positive environmental, social, and economic impacts. Since 2000, UBC’s energy management and conservation projects have decreased electricity consumption on campus by 55 GWh and natural gas consumption by 557,000 GJ annually. Our long-term goal is to consume energy more efficiently and to decouple energy consumption from GHG emissions, reducing our climate impact.

attributes.label: Department of Sociology
attributes.description: The Department of Sociology is involved in a wide scope of research examining areas such gender and sexuality, ethnicity, family and life course, environments, knowledge, and health and healthcare.

attributes.label: Sally Aitken
attributes.position: Professor and Associate Dean -- Research and Innovation, Department of Forest and Conservation SciencesUBC Faculty of Forestry.

attributes.label: Social-Ecological Systems (SES) Research Group
attributes.description: We conduct problem-focussed, interdisciplinary research relating to climate change adaptation, natural resources conservation, and wildfire. Our work is grounded in the environmental social sciences and centers on understanding how human behavioural, cultural, and governance dimensions drive change in social-ecological systems along particular pathways, and how these pathways might be restored or transformed to better serve communities, stakeholders and society.

attributes.label: Agricultural Water Innovations in the Tropics (AgWIT)
attributes.description: The Agricultural Water Innovations in the Tropics (AgWIT) partnership will test strategies to lower agricultural impacts on water resources while improving the resiliency of tropical agricultural systems to climate change. AgWIT will use a unique network of tropical agricultural water observatories to quantify water footprints and carbon footprints for crops under standard and alternative management practices.

attributes.label: Maged Senbel
attributes.position: Associate Professor, UBC School of Community and Regional Planning

attributes.label: Vancouver Campus Plan (falls under Land Use Plan)
attributes.description: The UBC Vancouver Campus Plan provides a cohesive framework for the campus’ current and future development and guides decision-making for the next 20 years.

attributes.label: Colin Brauner
attributes.position: Professor, Department of Zoology

attributes.label: Low Carbon Economy Research Theme
attributes.description: The Climate Intelligence Program (CIP) provides strategic, evidence- based analysis of climate science, technology, business, and policy. Leveraging a network of academic, private, and public sector partners, the CIP designs practical, cross-cutting solutions for our clients and partners in order to mobilize the innovation and entrepreneurship required to meet the challenges of climate change.

attributes.label: Infrastructure Development
attributes.description: UBC Infrastructure Development is responsible for the planning, development, renewal and renovation of campus facilities. We provide stewardship for all institutional facilities projects, including Housing and Athletics projects, at UBC Vancouver campus and Okanagan campus.

attributes.label: Pacific Salmon Ecology and Conservation Laboratory
attributes.description: We are committed to the study of salmonid ecology, behaviour and physiology, and to providing management systems with information needed for the conservation and sustainable use of fish resources.

attributes.label: Wall Solutions Initiative
